div.p: CHANGES: OR, Love in a Maze.
A COMEDIE, As it was presented at the Private House in Salisbury Court, by the Company of His Majesties Revels.
LONDON: Printed by G. P. for William Cooke, and are to be sold at his shop neere Furnivals Inne gate in Holborne, 1632.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONORABLE, THE LADY DOROTHIE SHIRLEY.
div.l: MAdame, who make the glory of your blood
No priviledge at all to be lesse good;
Pardon the rudenesse of a Comedy,
That (taught too great ambition) would fly
To kisse your white hand, and receive from thence
Both an authority, and innocence.
'Tis not this great man, nor that Prince, whose fame
Can more advance a Poem, than your name,
To whose cleere vertue truth is bound, and we,
That there is so much left for History.
I doe acknowledge custome, that to men
Such Poems are presented; but my pen
Is not engag'd nor can allow too farre
A Salick Law in Poetry, to barre
Ladies th'inheritance of wit, whose soule
Is active, and as able to controule,
As some 'usurpe the Chaire, which write a stile
To breath the Reader better than a mile;
But no such empty titles but my flame;
Nor will I sinne so much, to shew their name
In print; some servile Muses be their drudge,
That sweat to finde a Patron, not a Iudge.
To you, great Lady, then, in whom doe meet
Candor and Iudgement, humble as your feet
I vow these Papers, wishing you may see
Ioyes multiplied, to your eternitie.

closer.signed: Your Honors devoted Seruant, I A. SHIRLEY.

div.head: Prologus.
div.l: THat Muse whose Song within another Spheare
Hath pleased some, and of the best, whose eare
Is able to distinguish straines that are
Cleare, and Phebean, from the popular;
And sinfull dregs of the adulterate braine,
By mee salutes your Candor once againe;
And begs this noble favour, that this place,
And weake performances may not disgrace
His fresh Thalia; 'las our Poet knowes
Wee have no name, a torrent overflowes
Our little Iland, miserable wee,
Doe every day play our owne Tragedy:
But 'tis more noble to create than kill,
Hee saies, and if but with his flame, your will
Would joyne, wee may obtaine some warmth, and prove
Next them that now doe surfeit with your love.
Encourage our beginning, nothing grew
Famous at first, and Gentlemen, if you
Smile on this barren Mountaine, soone it will,
Become both fruitfull and the Muses hill.

list.item: Master Goldsworth, father to Chrysolina and Aurelia.
Master Thornay Gentlemen Lovers of Chrysolina, Aurelia and Eugenia.
Master Gerard Gentlemen Lovers of Chrysolina, Aurelia and Eugenia.
Master Yongrave Gentlemen Lovers of Chrysolina, Aurelia and Eugenia.

div.head: CHANGES OR, Loue in a Maze.
Actus primus, Scena primas.
div.stage: Enter at one doore Sir Iohn Wood-hamore, and Master Goldsworth, at the other M. Gerard, and Master Yongrave.

sp.speaker: Golds.
sp.p: I Heard your Neece, Sir, was not well, you should incourage her to take the aire some times.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Indeed shee's somewhat melancholy, and keepes
Her chamber:

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: 'T may prove inconvenient for
Her health, does she not languish for a husband?
Take heed oth' greene disease.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: I'le finde a cure,
If that will doe't; your daughters are not yet
Dispos'd of?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: No, but we have clients daily
That visit their affections; and while
We are speaking, here is one.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Ha, which of them? I hope not Master Yongrave.
Hee would engage his service to my Neece,
I shall not thinke him worthy, if he have
Two Hares afoot.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: He is a stranger to me,
But Master Gerard that holds conference with him,
Maintaines some correspondence with my daughters:
Pray let's observe.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Prethee come, venter in.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: No farther, you have obligation,
Excuse me, I have affaires, some other time
Ile waite on you.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: What needes this ceremony?
The faire ones will not blast you.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: 'Twere a sinne,
To thinke their beames could hurt.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Faith, I could wish
Thy affection not ingag'd, there's so much beauty
And goodnesse in this paire of sisters.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Doe not
Make me suspect your friendship, you would wish
Me miserable, not that I dispute
Their merit, but I must not yeeld to that
Will bring my faith and honour into question;
I have a Mistris, be you happy Sir in yours.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: I like this well, lets interrupt e'm;
Good fortune Master Yongrave.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: You are Sir,
Most opportunely met.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Kinde Master Gerard.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I had a present resolution,
To visit you at home, and your faire kins-woman.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: I shall be bold.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Pray enter.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Wee'l together: I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I am your humble servant,

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Come Master Yongrave. Exuent.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: This Gerard is a Gentleman of handsome parts,
And they say fortun'd, diligent in's courtship:
But it concernes me to be carefull in
Disposing of my children.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir Gervace Simple Sir, is newly entred,

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: His wisdome must be welcome: there's a Knight
With Lordships, but no mannors, one that has
But newly cast his country skin, came up
To see the fashions of the Towne, has crept
Into a Knight-hood which he paid for heartily
And in his best clothes is suspected for
A Gentleman.

div.stage: Enter Sir Ger. Simple, and his man Thumpe.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Thumpe, I have not yet the face to speake to her, but
'Tis no matter, and I can get her fathers and mothers good will.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: You have her mothers already.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I, I, shee's a Matron as they say, I came over her with
My Knight-hood, and begot a consent upon her quickly: I
Perceive 'tis an advantage for a man to weare spurres,
The rowell of Knight-hood does gingle in the eare of their
Vnderstanding.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: I doe wonder Sir, that you speake so well now, and
Want the audacity as they say to talke to your Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: So do I too, but I cannot help it: I was a Gentleman
Thou knowest but tother day. I have yet but a few
Complements, within a while I shall get more impudence
And then have at her.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: The father.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Pray heaven you may be sav'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Y'are charitable.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I am come Sir to doe my businesse.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: You may imagine as they say, and so forth your
Daughter is a very fine Gentlewoman, and may in due time be a Lady,
For I doe love her by this Mullet, there's a touch of my Heraldry.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Have you acquainted her,
How much you meane to honour us, how farre
Have you engaged her liking?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay, I n'er spoke to her in my life, nor do not meane in hast.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Not in hast Sir, 'twere no good manners to speake hastily to a Gentlewoman, to talke post (as they say) to his Mistresse; I am resolv'd to have your consent first, and then.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: It argues your discretion;

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I think so, some wiser than some, faith how doe y'like my face.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: I have seene worse in a beard,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Oh, ho, I tooke my choise of forty, this morning.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Did you so?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: My man knowes I broke a Looking. glasse into forty pieces,
I am sure, and this was the best face I could finde among
'Em all, look in my forehead, hast any skill in Palmistry?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Not I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: But this is nothing to the purpose (as they say,)
Where is my beautifull Mistresse, your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Which of e'm?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: No matter which.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: They are both within.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Oh, 'tis well, I will not speake with her, I told you
Before, but I hope I shall have your good Will.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: You meane to marry her.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: My Chaplaine shall.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: You are witty; I hope Sir, you will give me leave (as
They say) to deliberate, for after your example, I would
Doe nothing rashly, I will not give you my consent in
Hast Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: 'Tis wisdome, I can tarry, 'tis fit I should, commend
Me to the Virgin.

div.stage: As he goes forth he meetes Mistris Goldsworth.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: What, leaving us already, noble Sir?
Why husband, what doe y'meane? no more respect
To a man honorable? y'are not going Sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Yes faith, I love to be going, I cannot abide to stand
Still, Thumpe, take off my cloake; does my Rapier become Me?

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: Excellent well.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: This 'tis to be a compleat Gentleman, what a coxcombe was I before I came to towne, the countrey breeds so many Clownes; dost thinke my tenants will know mee now I am disguised

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: But what assurance can he give me, wife,
That he is able to get children?
For that's a thing materiall; I would not
Willingly sacrifice my daughter to
An Eunuch, and such a one may that Knight be,
For ought I know.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: What doe you talke of children?
Is he not honorable, a proper Knight?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: She does commend mee; doe not put on my cloke yet, let her survey my person.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: Shall not our daughter be a Lady, and I a
Ladies mother? And the Heralds know
That is some priviledge; you have seene many Eunuches
With a blacke beard; he is a man I warrant him,
He has the right haire, Husband, for a woman,
I know it by experience: tell not me,
Suppose he were an Eunuch, he I say
Is honorable, and any body can get children,
That's the least thing of a hundred
And the woman be but fruitfull.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Now Ile take my leave.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: Wil't please you Sir, to walke in, and speake to my daughter?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: No, I thinke it not the best way to speake to her, as I said,
In hast, what if I had an inventory of my good parts
First drawne to prepare her.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: And his father had not left him more land than braine,
His worship had beene but a poore foole.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Well, if she understand signes, have at her.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: Come, I will direct you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: My wife is passionate and affects this Knight
For's title, but I hope my daughter will
Submit to my election: how now:

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Here is a Gentleman desires accesse to you.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: A Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He may be a Lord by his traine,
A Page waites on him.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Some fresh Inamorato.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Save you Sir.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: And you Sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You doe not know me?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Not I Sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: 'Tis very likely: you have a daughter.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: I have two:

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Two? the better, there is more choise,
They want husbands.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: 'Twill become my care to provide 'm good ones.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You say well, what doe y' thinke of me?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: I know you not.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You told me that afore: may I see'm?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: They are not to be let out Sir by lease,
Or yeerely rent.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You mistake me; I come not for a lodging.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Nor to lye with them?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I come to take'm Sir, another way:
What portions have they?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: You should be a purse-taker, by your enquirie
After their mony, they have a round portion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: A cipher.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Nothing. I hope you have no mind to marry.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Ex nihilo nihil fit. I came to offer my selfe a
Servant in affection to one of your daughters, but
Nothing has converted me.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Doe y'heare Sir, a fine humorist: if they marry with
My consent, I can make figures, which added to
Their ciphers, may make up 2000 pound apiece: what
Is your name?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: My name is Caperwit.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Y'ave a dancing Name, I doe not thinke, but you
Write all the Coranto's.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Wit! wit by Mercury! I shall loue thy daughters the
Better for that: doe they affect Poetry?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: They reade nothing else.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Then they are wise; 'tis a Seraphicke contemplation;
I'le furnish them with the most excellent Poems—

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Of your owne composition?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: That is intimated, when I say excellent;
Your daughters shall be judge, let 'm vouchsafe
A subject to my muse, and prove the height
Of my imaginations.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: They are entring.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Thus breakes Aurora from the Easterne hills,
And chaseth night away, let me salute
Your rosie cheeke—

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Good morrow to you Sir, there is but one Aurora,
What doe y' make my Sister pray?

sp.speaker: Cap,
sp.l: She is the Sun it selfe.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: No Sir, I am the daughter of that Gentleman,
No sunne Ile assure you.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Whose golden beames doe gild this lower world,
Transfixing hearts, converting ribs of ice
Into a flame.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: What buffonry is this?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Lets heare his speech out, and my Sister be the Sunne,
Wee shall have day enough: a pretty Pageant!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Prethee doe not minde him.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Virgins, that equall all the graces, and
Only in this, that you are two, beneath them.
The miracles of beauty! for whose eyes
The Persians might forsake their god, and pay
Religious honour to this flame— what's he?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: A Gentleman, that would endeare himselfe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Has he any fancies in him? Can he ravish
The Ladies?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Ravish Ladies Sir? that's a dangerous matter.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: How many raptures does he talke a day?
Is he transported with Poeticke rage?
When was he stil'd Imperiall wit? who are
The Prince Electors in his Monarchy?
Can he like Celtick Hercules, with chaines
Of his divine tongue, draw the gallant tribe
Through every streete, whilst the grave senator
Points at him; as he walkes in triumph, and
Doth wish, with halfe his wealth, he might be young,
To spend it all in Sack, to heare him talke
Eternall Sonnets to his Mistris? ha?
Who loves not verse is damn'd—

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: How Sir? This Gentleman dares fight.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Who will fight with him?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: You doe not know his disposition.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p:
But I will, Sir; I have a great ambition to be of your acquaintance, I hope you will excuse these fancies of mine, though I were borne a Poet I will study to be your servant in Prose, yet if now and then my braines doe sparkle, I cannot helpe it, raptures will out, my Motto is Quicquid conabor,
the midwife wrapt my head up in a sheet of Sir Philip Sidney that inspired me, and my nurse descended from old Chaucer, my conversation has beene among the furies, and if I meete you in Apollo, a pottle of the best Ambrosia in the house, shall waite upon you.

div.stage: Enter Sir Gervase Simple, and Mistris Goldsworth.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: They are here Sir, at full view.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: What's he?

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: A Knight Ile assure you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Does he come
A wooing to the Ladies?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: After the Spanish fashion—
A farre off.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: Daughter, I must counsell you to respect
This honorable man, you doe not know
What 'tis to be a Lady, and take place,
Such titles come not every day, observe
With what a comely garbe he walkes, and how
He bends his subtle body, take him a my word,
A man of his complection loves a woman naturally.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: A pretty motion.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: Pray come neerer Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: You shall pardon me for that, I know
My distance.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Will he not speake to her?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: You should doe well to furnish him with an oration, a spoonefull of Aganippe's well, and a little of your Salt, would season, if not pickle him.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Should I so wast the bright Minerva's dew, to pickle a Mushrome?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Thumpe, she lookes upon me, to say truth, I am but a bashfull puppy.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: Your worship is more than a puppy.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I, I know I am an old dog at her mother, but and I should be hang'd, I have not impudence enough to speak to her: does not that Gentleman laugh at mee?

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: He is very merry with her father.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: 'Tis very suspitious, would I had a good jest to get of withall.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: You shall command the duty of a daughter,
But I hope mother, you will give me leave
To love before I marry I have yet
No argument of his affection,
But what you please to bring me it becomes not
My modesty to court him, and give up
My heart before I heare him say, he meanes
To meete and entertaine it.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: 'Tis a fault, and I must blame him, that he is no forwarder.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I will accuse him—

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Doe so.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Love, forgive me this excuse, my heart is fixt,
I finde another written here.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: I doe salute you, venerable Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: You may salute me at your pleasures, but you are mistaken, I am no more venerable than your selfe; my name is Sir Gervace Simple.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: And I am one of his Gentleman Vshers, Sir, that follow him.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Heroick Sir, I doe adore your physnomy. Now by the dust of my Progenitors—

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: There's a fine oath!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: You looke like the Nine Worthies.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I have been taken for 'em a hundred times.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Fairer than Plutos selfe king of the shades.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: That King was a poore kinsman of mine, and indeed Wee had one complexion.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: The Divell you had?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Sir, I am sorry, I cannot stay wi'you, but pray if you meete any of the nine Worthies, or my Cosen Pluto, commend me to 'em, I shall be glad to meete you, or them, at any Taverne, betweene Cheape and Charingcrosse, and so I remaine yours, or not his owne, sau's complement.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: When will you please Sir Gervace, to visit us agen? Nay, it shall be yours. He complements, Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Now my foot's in.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: But that I see't, I should not have beleeved there were such a foole in nature.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: In this variety of servants, I
Acknowledge you greatly honour me, and in the presence
Of both your parents to vouchsafe this favour,
Doubly obliges me.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: You are most welcome.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: You may beleeve my sister, she n'er speakes
But by direction of her heart.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I am confident,
Nor hath she any vertue, which you doe not
Divide with her; your twins in birth and goodnesse!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Y'are bountifull in character.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Ile not oppose you Sir, and you can winne their opinion.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: 'Tis enough, I shall be proud to serve you;
But at this present, with your noble licence,
I take my leave, there is a Lord expects
To meete me at a Taverne, that has come
Fourescore and nineteene mile, to heare an elegy of
My composition

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: He deserves to enjoy you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ile attend the Ladies, when my starres will be more propitious, ith' interim wearing your beautifull figures in my heart, I kisse your white hand— Exit.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I thinke the stocke of his discourse be wasted,
And he returnes to take up more on's credit,
Vntill he breake agen, the Towne is full
Of these vaineglorious flashes.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Chrisolina,
You see what store of servants yee attract,
Plenty of louers but I hope you will
Be ruld, and take my counsell: which of all
And be plaine wi'mee, hold you best opinion of?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: You will not Sir, be angry, if I answer you justly.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: No no, tell me.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I confesse,
I now doe feele the power of love, untill
That Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Which, which Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: By his faire merit, won my hearts consent,
I had my freedome.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Master Gerard?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: The same, oh Sir, there's no comparison
With him and those that proffer us their service:
Sir Gervace is but title, tother noise,
Empty of all reality and worth,
There is my choise, more pretious to my thoughts, Pointing to Ger.
Than all mankind without him, and I hope
You will be kind in your allowance Sir.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: You might have us'd lesse haste in your election,
Or first acquainted me, you shall doe well
To keepe possession of your heart awhile;
But Ile consider; send your sister to me:
What say you daughter to Sir Gervace?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Nothing, as much as he hath said to me.
I affect worth, not shew; and in my choise
I hope your judgement Sir will meete.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: I like this well, be obedient.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What thinke you Sir, of Master Gerard?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: You doe not love him?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I should then bely
My heart when I deny him my best love,
He needes not boast his worth, like those whom Nature
And Art have left unfurnish'd, hee's a man
For birth, for education, for his fortune,
Worthy a nobler wife, than shee that now
Commends him to you.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Would you marry him?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I know not that man in the world beside,
I would call husband, in my soule I am
Already his, and if you will not be
Held cruell to your daughter—

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: How's this?
Both in love with the same man? my care will be
To a great purpose, this is very strange;
Send your sister to me; come hither, come hither,
You are not yet contracted to that Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ch
sp.l: No such thing has past.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: But you are content to take him for your bridegroome, I meane Master Gerard.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: And call it happinesse;

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Your mother calls: so, so, doe you heare? Aurelia, doe you love that Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Very good, when your wedding clothes come home, pray give me leave to pay for 'em, and the dinner too. I say nothing of a portion, goe after your sister: hum, this is very pretty, faith, let me be bold to aske you a question Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: My answer shall be just, and free.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Which of my daughters doe you love best?
As y'are a Gentleman the truth, if you affect either, it
Is quickly answered.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: The truth is, as you aske, I love neither.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: How, doe you love none of 'em both, they are very well rewarded.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.p: Love neither of them best, they are so equall in beauty, and desert, by both I sweare, I cannot preferre any.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: You'd not have two wives against the Statute?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: When I have the happinesse to speak with one alone,
There's so much sweetnesse in her, such a troope
Of graces waiting on her words and actions,
I love her infinitely, and thinke it blessing
To see her smile, but when the tother comes
In presence, in her eie she brings a charme
To make me dote on her; I am divided,
And like the trembling Needle of a Dyall,
My heart's afraid to fixe, in such a plenty
I have no starre to sayle by.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: This is stranger.
Than all the rest, but doe you love e'm both?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I dare not call it my misfortune Sir,
And yet I know not.—

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: What will become o'this?
I'st possible? My daughter will be mad if this humor
Hold, and I am little better while I thinke on't:
Ile to e'm agen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: On whom shall I complaine for my hard fate?
Love is not innocent enough to bee
A child, yet Poets give him Deity,
Fond men! prove it in me, thou quiverd Boy,
That love with equall flame two Mistresses,
I will beleeve thee a god, and kisse thy dart,
Furnish my bosome with another heart. Exit.

div.head: Actus Secundus.
div.stage: Enter Sir Iohn Woodhamore, Master Yongrave.

sp.speaker: Woodhamore.
sp.l: I Am her Keeper; expect here a while,
And Ile prepare her. Exit.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Ile attend; poore Gentlewoman,
Borne with more freedome than thou livest, thy parents
Left thee not rich to be a prisoner,
Nay worse, a prey to this hard man, who hath
Sold thee already, for if I obtaine
Thy love— I heare e'm comming.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Gentle Neece,
Misconster not my actions, 'tis my care
Of thee, and to satisfie the duty
I owe to my dead Brother, thy kinde parent:
I thus restraine thee, thou art young, and canst not.
Being so good thy selfe, suspect the world
Hath any false men in't; I know there are
Gallants, that study to undoe such Virgins
As thou art, that will flatter and betray
Thy fortunes to their riot, this unhappinesse
I would prevent, and have new found a man,
Into whose armes I may deliver up
The wealth that I am trusted with.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Hee's welcome: Pray what's your businesse?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.p: You may understand, partly by what your Vncle hath delivered.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: You come a wooing doe ye not? Heigho!

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: I'le leave you at opportunity. Exit.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Troth, if you be a good man, bee not tedious,
I doe not love set speeches nor long praises,
I hope y'ave made no verses o'my haire,
Acrosticks o'my name, I hate them worse
Than witchcraft, or the place I live in: if
You be a sutor, put me out of my paine,
Quickly I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I am one would be your servant.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: My servant? what can you doe?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I can love you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I cannot helpe it, 'tis none of my fault.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Your beauty makes me,
Which cannot bee without as faire a soule.
I dare beleeve my eyes, which till this present,
Could never reach more than your face, and that
At too unkind a distance, from your window;
I have enquired your fortune, and lamenting
With loving pitty, such a noble creature
Should be confind to narrow limits, come
To bring you freedome, make you mistresse of
Your liberty, and my selfe, if you can thinke
Me worthy of your love: I doe not court
Your fortune, but your selfe, and if I urge
With too much haste, what great ones might be proud
To expect, after much sute, and that you cannot
Finde in your tongue consent, encourage me,
But for the present with one smile.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I cannot,
Vnlesse I counterfeit, I have not smil'd
These ten moneths; if a sigh will pleasure you,
I can afford enough to breake your heart,
And yet I live. Walke into the other roome,
You'l find an alteration in the ayre,
And thinke you come into a mist, which I
Made all with my owne sighes, but I would not
Infect you so; you seeme an honest Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Her sorrowes helpe the growth of my affection;
What will she be in peace, that is so lovely
In her distresse; I wish you would impose
Something on me, to settle your sad thoughts,
I would imbrace a danger, to assure
The quiet of your minde.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: 'Tis in the power
Of one, that would be kinde to helpe me, but—

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Make me that friend.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: You may love me too much,
To undertake that taske.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Too much I cannot.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Oh yes, for though I should esteeme him deare,
And call him my true friend, that in this storme
Would lend a cord to save me, yet such is
The misery of the imployment, he must not
Love me too well that does it.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Bee more plaine
And let mee never hope to be cald yours,
If I refuse any command, that may
Or profit, or delight you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I release these hasty
Protestations.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I pray trust me.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I will, although
Every syllable you speake, makes me suspect,
You will repent this freedome. If you will doe
A gratefull Office to me, in your person,
Give this paper to a Gentleman. gives him a letter.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Your name?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: In the direction
You'l find it, with all necessary circumstance
To meet with him

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: This all: you doe not well.
To mocke my honest heart with this cheape service.
I was in earnest, when I promisd more,
Than carriage of a letter.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: If you please
To make it then a perfect act of Noblenesse,
You may take notice, that I long have loved him,
And if you finde him cold, in the perusall:
Tell him I had the promise of his faith,
When I gave up my heart, i'th presence of
A thousand Angels, that will witnesse it:
If yet hee bee not soft to stirre up his
Compassion, tell him how I live, and languish,
You may report you saw mee weepe, I have not
Much more to say, if you will doe this favour,
Twill be an argument of your respect,
I see your resolution cooles already.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Tis a severe imployment, but Ile doe
Something, pray honour mee to kisse your hand,
I have not yet deserv'd to reach your lippe:
Content dwell in your bosome.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: What successe?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I hope well, some affaires
Call mee away. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Good Master Yongrave: how doe you like this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I shall desire to see him agen, my heart
Is light upon sudden, please you Vncle
Ile in, and play a lesson o'my Lute. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Doe what you please, I rellish not your ayre,
Thats onely sweet to mee that profit brings,
There is no musicke without golden strings.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Was ever Maid so miserable in her affection?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Is not my fate as cruell?
Cannot wee love him still, and yet bee sisters?
I hope we may; the love I beare to him
Shall not destroy my piety to you:
Nature hath fram'd us two in person, but wee are both one in heart.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Indeed we are; Wee are too much one,
And both love one too much, for either to enjoy him.

sp.speaker: Au
sp.l: Say not so, give me a little time and I will try
How I can give him you; I will perswade
My heart to let him goe.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Alas poore sister,
Why should you give him me? it is no argument;
Because I came one minute into life
Before you, therefore you should render first
To me, what is so pretious to your selfe;
Rather let me begin, that was first made
Acquainted to the world, resigne to thee,
And make thee happy by enjoying him.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: But doe you know the miserable consequence?
For if you love him with that truth, and fervour
You speake of, (as it were a sinne in me
Not to beleeve it,) can you looke for lesse
Than death, to see mee mistresse of his faith,
And lead in nuptiall triumph to the Church?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I cannot tell—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Or if it did not kill you
So soone, I know the sorrow would distract you.
How can I smile to see my sister weepe,
Away her eyes, and tell the jarring minutes
With hasty sighes to know her selfe forsaken?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: And can it be, you could doe lesse, that love him
As well as I, to see him made my husband,
Would it not make you melancholy sister,
And ofte retire into the darke to weepe,
Could you behold us freely kisse, embrace
And goe to bed together, remembring that
You gave this friend to me from your owne
Heart, and live?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Why let me dye then,
Rather than you, I shall perhaps obtaine
Some charitable Epitaph, to tell
The world, I died to save my sisters life;
Tis no such thing to dye.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: This is agen
Our misery, it is not in our power
Be resignation, to assure to either
His love, he only must determine it,
Wee cannot guide his passion.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Nor himselfe
Direct it, as he now appeares divided,
May be, it would be fortunate for both,
Would he be more particular.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: That makes
Our flame increase, that he protests he loves
Vs both, so equally.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: 'Tis very strange.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Let us then joyne our argument to perswade him,
To point out one of us to be his Bride,
Tother in time, may hope to gaine her freedome;
I know not what I say— we both must plead
Against our selves: see, he is come already.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: The scales are even still, that one had lesse
Perfection, to make the doubtfull ballance
Give difference in their value; but I wrong
Their vertues to wish either any want,
That equally incline my soule to love 'em.
Iustice I now consent, thou shouldst be blinde,
My eyes are but the cause I cannot see,
And will not give my judgement leave to make
Distinction of these two Democritus,
I doe allow thy rashnesse, ad confesse
Then thou didst rectifie thy contemplation
When thou didst lose thy sight. Which of these two
Instruct me love, that tother? both? what fate
Hovers about my choice? Were it not sinne
I would be blind, as Poets fancie love,
Into whom now I am transform'd, that then
My soule not looking through these glasses, might
With inward speculation ayme at her,
That is the happiest, if one can be so.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Sir, if wee be not troublesome—

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: You cannot.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: To interrupt your meditations, wee have a sute.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Both? it must needes be granted,

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Nor let us suffer in our modesties,
If our request seeme strange.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Tis a command,
And I must needes obey; you two divide this Empires

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: You prepare; we dispute not
The strangenesse of your love, but pitty it,
And are so ready in our owne affection
To answer your opinion of us both,
That if you can collect, what devide
On two, and place it fairely upon one,
Choose whom you will make happie.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: We expect not
Your hasty answer, though wee both desire
A swift end to your trouble.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: I pray stay. Exit.
I would determine now, but cannot— faire ones,
Was ever lover so perplext? I must resolve.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Why how now Franke? what melancholy?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: How came you hither?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Why o'my feet:
I was at your lodging to enquire for you,
And here they told me I should finde you.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Yes,
Here I am lost indeed; prethee excuse my dulnesse.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What's the matter, come I ghesse
The cause, which of these Gentlewomen is't? I saw 'em.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Didst? and how dost like 'em prethee?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I doe like 'em so well, that I could wish—

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Which, which of them?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Faith I cannot tell, the worst of 'em both a-bed wi'me.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Thy wishes are
Not modest: couldst thou love one of them nobly?
Ha? thou hast a person and fortune to invite thy
Entertainement, come let me counsell you.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: To what?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: To love, and to a blessing: couldst thou see
So sweet a paire, and feele no burning shaft?
Hast thou a soule about thee, that is capable
Of knowledge and delight? didst ever love?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Yes once, and I thinke heartily, for the time,
But I ha'drowned her.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: In Sacke, I thinke as gallants lose their Mistresses,
By drinking their health too often.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Prethee doe not trifle.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What wouldst have me answer? I can love.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: A woman?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What dost make of mee?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: With honour?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And honesty, if I see cause.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Enough; thou shalt have cause
Within two minutes, shalt but see agen
These sisters, and be proud to be a servant,
I prophesie already; oh my friend!

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Pray take me wi'you.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Yes, thou shalt goe with me
And speake to 'em, and be amaz'd as I am,
To know there are such creatures.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I ha' seene a multitude of faire ones.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: All other women
Are but like pictures in a gallery,
Set off to th'eye, and have no excellency
But in their distance; but these two, farre off
Shall tempt thee to just wonder, and drawne neere
Can satisfie thy narrowest curiosity:
The stocke of woman hath not two more left,
To rivall them in graces.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: You speake for 'em,
I may goe farther, and fare worse,—. Ile not
Consider more on't, lets to 'em, stay—
Which of these two's your mistresse? let me know
Where to direct my service.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: That question
Hath puzled mee already.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Say, which is't you best affect?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: I love em both, so equally,
I know not which to name.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: How, both? what then
Should I doe with em? art thou mad?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: A little,
Containe thy selfe, and call thy reason to thee,
Although it be the cruelty of my fate,
I can be no barre to thee; I can enjoy
But one, and yet thou shalt have choice
Of both, thou art not thus my rivall,
But my friend, reliefe of my distraction for shee
Whom thou refusest, if thou canst endeare thy selfe to either,
In my heart shall meet a cleere and perfect entertainment.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Hum.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Canst thou resolve? winne either,
And we both grow happy at once.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: You say well, this is faire—

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: They are here.

div.stage: Enter Simple and M. Golds. at one doore, and Thump, Chris. and Aurel. at the other.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: With your favour I must chide you Sir, not once speak to My daughter, she expects to be courted with kisses and imbraces.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I, I, I could kisse her all over, and imbrace her too, but I have an imperfediment, I cannot speake as I would doe; but let mee alone a little, Ile try, let me see, and I hanot forgot my verses.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Here they are, Ile not trouble you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I will leave this Gentleman;
Hee is my best friend Ladies.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: You oblige us more to respect him.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I hope you will be just,
At my returne, when I declare my selfe.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Sir, you sh'anot need to urge it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I am your honourer. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Now Thump, I am resolv'd to speak to her, whatsoever Come on't; hum, hum. Enter Mr. Goldsworth.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: What another sutor?
I were best locke up my daughters, they'l be smothered with Gentlemen: Sir Gervace you are a welcome man.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: You shall see, if I doe not speake to her, now
Now, and to the purpose, in spight of the divell.

sp.speaker: Thump
sp.l: Stroke me o'th back. He plucks Aur. by the gowne.
There's something in my head, and t'were out.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: I hope you doe not meane your braines.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Would somebody lov'd me, but as well, as I loved Somebody.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Now 'tis out.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: La you there, I thinke I talked to her.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: But in my opinion you were quickly daunted.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Was I so? well marke me now, now, I will wincke As hard as I can, and then I'me sure she cannot put me out.

div.stage: Sim. takes Cap. by the hand.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Beauty—

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: How now? what meanes this?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Let me but kisse thy hand, and tell
How much I love thee; I know very well
Thou art a Phenix, beautious and bright,
And dost burne every man for thy delight
Thy eyes are Sunne and Moone, not to be match'd.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: This was intended for you sister.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Thy haire is fine as gold, thy chin is hatch'd
With silver, needs must brazen be my face,
That cannot come into thee with a grace.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Before or after meat.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Sweet, heare me out.
But this I know, I am thy faithfull Lover,
Oh quench my fire.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Or else the pot run's over.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Y'are in the right:
Accept me for thy servant, not thy foe,
For I doe love thee better than any man in the whole world can doe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Come kisse me then, and open thy faire eyne.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Gentlemen, rest you merry; Thump,
By this hand Ile bee drunke presently.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: And you had taken my counsell, you had done so
Before you came hither: Wine is armour of proofe. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Ladies I am sorry, this rude fellow has
Abus'd your eare, with harsh, and untun'd numbers.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Your verses have a tune belike

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I came a purpose, to present a copie
Of verses that should make your genius stand
O'th tip-toe, list to me, and grow immortall.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: We shall be troubled now.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: If please you Lady
Weel walke a side, I have something of more weight
I would impart. Ex.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Ile leave him too. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Master Caperwit, before you read, pray tell me,
Have your verses any adjectives?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Adjectives, would you have a Poem without
Adjectives? they are the flowers, the grace of al our language:
A well chosen Epithete doth give new soule
To fainting Poesie, and makes every verse
A bride, with Adjectives we baite our lines,
When we doe fish for Gentlewomens loves,
And with their sweetnesse catch the nibling eare
Of amorous Ladies, with the musicke of
These ravishing Nownes, we charme the silken Tribe,
And make the Gallant melt with apprehension
Of the rare word: I will maintain t against
A bundle of Grammarians, in Poetry,
The Substantive it selfe, cannot subsist
Without an Adjective.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: But for all that,
Those words would sound more full, me thinks, that are not
So larded, and if I might counsell you,
You should compose a Sonnet cleane without e'm:
A row of stately Substantives, would march
Like Switzers, and beare all the field before e'm;
Carry their weight, shew faire like Deeds enrold,
Not Writs, that are first made, and after fild.
Thence first came up the title of blancke verse,
You know Sir, what blancke signifies? when the sense
First framed, is tyed with Adjectives like points,
And could not hold together without wedges:
Hang't tis pedanticke, vulgar Poetry,
Let children when they versifie, sticke here,
And there these pidling words for want of matter:
Poets write Masculine numbers.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You have given me a pretty hint, tis new.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: And will bee gratefull,
My daughter will affect it much the better,
And twill be honour, if shee be the first,
To whom so choice a Poem is presented.
I wish you well Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You oblige my service,
I will bestow these verses o'my footman;
They'l serve a Chambermaid, let me see
I want a little quickning, two or three
Infusions of sacke will heighten mee,
And make my Genius dance, then Lady, Lady— Gone?
Shee's hard of Soule, but I must supple her,
And there's a conceit new strucke upon my braine
Will doo't, {non-Roman} {non-Roman} {non-Roman} forces united conquer,
Lady grow soft, if merit cannot prove
Happy, wee must use policie in love. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: No more; you doe not well to wrong your friend,
That trusts you with his bosome.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Faire one, heare mee.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: He gave you welcome hither, and you practise
Vnworthily to supplant him.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: You are too
Severe, I have no thought so wicked Lady,
Deny me not that liberty, which all
The Creatures have, to wish their owne felicity;
Which cannot bee without you, hee will not
Repine to see mee happy in your love.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: In seeming to extenuate your error,
You thus enlarge it, and bring into question
The honour of your friend, for whom I must
Though weake, rise up a Champion for his vertue,
And to beate off all argument, on your part
To move for my affection, know, he is next heaven,
The onely object of my heart, nor can it know a change.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And yet if you collect your selfe, you are not
The onely Mistresse of his heart, your sister hee loves
As well as you; your pardon fairest, tis possible,
Hee may preferre her too, since neither piety nor law allowes,
Hee can bee husband at one time, to both.
Then let discretion guide you first to freedome,
I love you not with halfe a heart, but all;
Heaven knowes with all, at every looke you doe
Transfixe me, and can onely cure the wound
With the same eyes, if they but smile upon it.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I must not heare you plead thus, you appeare
Nor friend to him, nor me; so fare you well. Exit.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I am caught, by this good day I am, and know not
How now to helpe my selfe: a hansome thing!
What a blind buzzard is this Iackanapes Cupid?
Pox of his bird-bolt, Ile not leave her:
Yet I may be too forward; I am punish'd:
Venus, thy pardon, I beseech thee,
If thou beest not hard-hearted, as the Poets feine,
Speake to thy Boy to fetch his Arrow backe,
Or strike her with a sharpe one, make her squeake,
And Ile allow thee a Goddesse. Ha, 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Before thou speak'st to me, let me peruse
Thy face, Ile tell my selfe how thou hast sped:
Well? is't not so? Yet doe not answer me,
That smile does not shew cleere, there is some cloud
Ith' corner of thy forehead, that would spread,
And darken all thy face.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Your Physiognomy is quite discredited.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Hast prevail'd? With which? why now thou art to tedious.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: With the eldest, Chrysolina.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Ha, what sound was that? With Chrysolina?
I prethee what of her, I love her deerely;
Thou hast not filcht away her heart, it grew with mine.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Hast thou not seene the Woodbine,
That honey-dropping tree, and the lov'd Bryer,
Embrace with their chaste boughs, twisting themselves,
And weaving a greene net to catch the birds,
Till it doe seeme one body, while the flowers
Wantonly runne to meet and kisse each other?
So 'twas betwixt us two.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I meane the yongest.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: What my Aurelia?
Thou canst not rob me so: the amorous Turtles
Have but their imitation from our love;
The Pelican loves not her yong so well,
That digs upon her brest an hundred springs,
When in her blood she bathes the innocent birds,
As I doe my Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Godbewi'y',— I know not how to please you, nor to answer.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I prethee stay.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Engage me in a businesse?
Nay, thrust me oth' lime-twigs, to set you
At liberty, when your owne wings were glu'd
Toth' bush, and d'ye reward me at his fashion?
And I had knowne it, you shou'd ha' fluttered.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I forgot my selfe, I prethee pardon me,
I will excuse thee when thou art in love.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Then doe so now, and you'l be temperate and heare me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Speake, I am recollected.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: And I am in love.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Thou didst name both, thou art so unhappy.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Your humors lead me to't, but I shall tell you?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Which, which of them did most encourage thee?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Be not you passionate still, but give me thanks,
And call me fortunate, she has halfe consented.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I shall be lost ith' darke: declare which.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Which? why the eldest; which? Chrysolina,
Now be you advised, and court the other.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Halfe consenting.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I may say three quarters, and not lye.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Tis false; and such a staine thou throwest upon that Virgin,
Thy blood deserves to purge.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: You doe not meane to play the foole thus:
Pox upon this madnesse: I wo not fight with you,
And I will love that Gentlewoman:
I thought I had done you a courtesie.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So thou hast, if it be true.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Have you a mind to be the everlasting madcap?
And you can couple with both, I can resigne;
Poore Gentlewoman, shel ha' the worst on't.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: But I prethee tell me,
With what Art didst thou so soone win her to thee?
It was some moneths 'ere I prevail'd; and were I not
Confident of thy honesty, I should
Suspect some witchcraft.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: There is an Art
In wooing, not reveal'd to every man,
Which he that knowes, shall doe more with a Maid
In some minute, than others in a twelve-moneth.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'T must be a luckie minute.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I, he must take her ith' nicke; and court her
In the precise minute: yet it may be, she
In pitty of my sufferings or mistrusting
She might not be the first in your election,
Inclin'd the sooner: Now would I have you,
Without more ceremony, neglect the wench
That I have chosed: D'ye marke? neglect her,
And addresse all your courtship to the yongest,
Your meaning will be cleerely understood
A both sides; so you shall with ease, enlarge
Your owne heart, fixe on one whose armes already
Are open to yee, and make my path direct,
Without any rub to the other. Is this sense?
Obey it then; set on afore with your Mistris
A hand gallop, if I overtake you not, let me swing
I'th bridle, and set a saddle o'my backe, and let all the
Fooles in the Towne ride me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Wee must not bee too rash, lets walke, and thinke on't. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: TH'art a brave Wench.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You are growne bold of late.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I thinke so, gramercy Sacke: Come kisse mee, wo't thou be a Lady?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I have no great ambition.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Ile buy thee a Parrat to morrow, and a Monkey:
Here, take this Ring.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Pray keepe it, and let me tell you Sir my mind.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And Ile tell thee mine, that's one for another.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Briefly then.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Be as briefe as you please, I can be as briefe as you, and tedious too: I know thou lovest mee: Sirra, didst thinke I was such a fearefull coxcombe as I made my selfe? No, I know when to be Lion, and when to be a Hare. But prethee tell me plainely, when shall we matrimony it, ha? thou dot'st upon my good parts; come, speake to me, prethee be not bashfull.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I feare you wo'not understand me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Speake no language, and I warrant, I know Greeke and Latine, I learn'd my Accidence.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Then know, I doe not love you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: You do not love me, Sir: then I have lost my labour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I make no doubt it will appeare so,
I could be of the humour of some Mistrisses,
By some slight favours to encourage you,
Accept your gifts, extoll your wit, invent
New wayes to melt your gold, beside the Exchange,
And petticoat imbroyderies.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Thou sha't have smocke imbroyderies; nay, thy very skinne shall be imbroydered.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Have every day some progresse for your Coach,
And tire you worse than your foure Flanders Mares;
And then laugh at you too: but I am honest,
And will deserve your nobler character:
I tell you what you must expect, in troth
I cannot love you, pray leave off in time,
And let this satisfie you.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: This satisfie? why this is even as good nothing.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: It is all that I can promise you.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Though you cannot love me,
It shall be for your honour to marry me.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: By no meanes.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: What, not marry me neither?
Then be no Lady, that I first pronounce:
Secondly know, I am resolved, your Mother
Shall understand it, by these Hilts.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I would advise you rather to be silent,
And take your leave like a good Christian Lover:
If you betray my honest meaning so,
And move her to impatience, I shall wish you
Ith' West Indiaes. Enter Mistris Golds.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Here shee comes.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: Sir I hope, you and my Daughter are agreed,

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: And the conditions please mee infinitely;
Mother you never plac'd your commendation
Vpon a Gentleman so Noble, such
Plenty of honour dwels in him, I must
Bee happy in his imbraces.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Oh ho! is't come about agen?

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: Nay nay, I told you, you should find him honourable.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Wee understand each other perfectly,
Hee has so sweet a soule, I may have any thing;
Hee has promised me the finest Parrats.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Oh I, and Madgehowlets that can speake all languages.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: Nay, and hee'le performe:
Well, for this act of duty, I shall finde
Some gold beside thy portion, i'th meane time
Ile move thy father to conclude the marriage:
And here hee is already.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Looke you Sir,
These turnes you put mee too; doe not beleeve
I beare one thought more of good-will for this,
If you suspect it otherwise; because
I carry it sweet and pleasing to my mother,
Who is so zealous in your cause, I'le sweare
Your worship is the most unwelcomm'st man
I'th world to mee.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'm glad shee is not gone yet.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What need you distrust?
Hee'l know precisely when we must be married,
Is jealous of delayes, wo'not beleeve I love him,
Till the Priest hath seald me his i'th Church, hee sayes.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: These are tricks, demurres, your daughter is not sober.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: He meanes serious.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: She doth but mocke—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Who would thinke you could dissemble.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: Sir have patience, I have not beene so hasty,
To become tedious at last, referre that to my care;
Since you have made a marriage in your hearts,
The Church shall soone confirme it.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What doe y' thinke of this?
Faith yet be wise and leave this wooing,
I shall maintaine this humour to my mother,
And finde a crotchet to come off with honour, you have not
Yet my hate, pray let's bee friends, and never meet agen,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: This is very fine yfaith, if I do not study some mischiefe.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Conceale for your owne shame.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: How doe'y like 'em Lady? 't pleasd your father
To impose somewhat severely on my Muse,
But your Divine acceptance shall declare it
A Crowned Poem, most illustrious Simple,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Simple mee no more than I simple thee.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir, there is a Lady enquires for Master Caperwit.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: A Lady out of complement? tis hee.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Shee seemes of Noble quality, she has Coach and faire
Attendants, and cals her selfe the Lady Bird.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Good Cupid is it shee?
Who gave her direction to finde mee here?
An honourable Lady, I confesse, and hath a fortune
Noble like her birth, tis the rich Aldermans widdow,
The great Bird that dyed at's Country house, a Kinsman
To the Ravens of the City; by no meanes admit her,
Shee'le betray her foolish Passion.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Some few dayes agoe
I did by chance, but drop a complement,
How much I was her servant, and she tooke it
To'th heart, and ever since hath sought occasion
To expresse her love to mee, poore Gentlewoman,

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: You cannot helpe it.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Tis one, but of the myriad of Ladies
That have been taken—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: With your tropes and figures,

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: No matter, let her come, it were not civill
Sir to deny your selfe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Sheele tire all patience:
But Lady, be assur'd my heart is dedicate
To you, and were all women kind in ballance
With your divinest person, their light scale
Would kicke the Firmament, or comming downe,
Bee lost i'th middle Region of the ayre,
Or bee converted to a Cloud to weepe
Vpon the earth, for being so much exceld.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Where's this Footman?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Trot my Ladies Footman,

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Goe pray my Vncle Sir Walter Cormorant
To dine with me to morrow— And doe y'heare?
Tis in your way to aske if my Cosin Bulfinch,
The Steward of my Land, bee come to Towne,
Hee lies in Fleetstreet betweene Hawke and Buzzard.
I'th afternoone, remember Sirrah, that
You goe to Master Kite, that lives i'th Poultry,
And say I shall expect the thousand pound,
Was lent him upon morgage:
Sir, beseech your Noblenesse excuse mee,
The affaires so neerely doe concerne mee, with
A Gentleman, (now your guest,) that I presumed
It should not bee offence, if I tooke hold
Of this occasion, to speake with him.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Madame, you need plead no excuse for that,
Command your freedome here: Daughters, my Lady
Would have some private conference,

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: By no meanes
Let me appeare so troublesome, your presence
Will be no hurt to my designe, you shall
Command a great deale more.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: 'Twas cunningly prepared,

sp.speaker: Bi.
sp.l: Sir, after all, let me obtaine your priviledge.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Proceed.—

sp.speaker: Bi.
sp.l: I shall accuse my selfe of too much boldnesse,
If you neglect mee Sir before all these;
I come not to disturbe you, nor to publish
What you have taken from mee.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I hope shee will lay some felony to his charge.

sp.speaker: Bi.
sp.p: But Sir, you might have been so kind, to have seene your friend once in three dayes.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I must be pardon'd Widow,
The glasse that tells the hower, hath not more sands,
Than there be Ladies waite to catch me up
To spend my time with 'em, they breake my dreames,
With importunity, and allow me but
One minute in a weeke, to say my prayers.

sp.speaker: Bi.
sp.l: Among them all, there is not one
That more desires your happinesse.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Tis more your goodnesse Lady, than desert,
Or provocation in me.

sp.speaker: Bi.
sp.l: Y'are modest,
And thus increase your value.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Your favours are acknowledg'd, and take up
Much of my studies, how I may be active
In service to reward 'em, still preserving
My liberty, I must not be confind
Or wedg'd in; all that's good in nature ought
To be communicable, if you have
Promis'd your selfe more of me, than as you are
Allowd, an excellent part o'th commonwealth,
Tis justice you correct the imagination,
Perhaps you'l say, you love me.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: A fine Dialogue:

sp.speaker: Bi.
sp.l: My blushes speake me guilty, and I feare
Betray my frailty to these Gentlewomen:
You'l sinne against your knowledge Sir, to make
A question how much I esteeme you, be not
A tyrant, if my opinion of your worth
Prevaile against my modesty, to say
I cannot choose but love you, tis my fate,
My breeding never suffred, but in this,
That I should lose my selfe to court a man,
Ambitious of my favour; tis in vaine
To tell you, with what art, my eyes have beene
Courted by great ones for their smile, for you
Will turne them all to teares.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Alas poore Lady:
I pitty her, what doth she see in him,
To draw this passion?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: May be, I am engag'd
To another beauty.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: That's my feare indeed;
For who can looke with eyes like mine upon you,
And not be tempted to the same desires?
But be not Sir deceived, all forheads are not
True glasses of the minde, and beauty alone
Deserves not such a blessing; young men doe
Too hastily betray themselves to miserie,
That thinke no heaven but in their Mistresse face,
Looke on my fortune, which doth spread more riches,
Than pleasure can instruct thee wayes to spend,
Delights shall streame themselves into thy bosome,
Honour and titles of the state shall woe
Thy name to put them on and not be thine
But thou their ornament.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Affection must
Flow uncompeld, you may be pleas'd to take
Some other time to finish this discourse.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: I may suspect I have offended these;
But pray interpret fairely, noble Sir, to Simple.
I doe beseech you pardon
The errors that you finde in us fraile women,
Yet I beleeve you would not use me so
Neglectfully: tis time, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Wee are your humble servants.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Sir, if you will not affect this Ladie,
I hope some other may.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: And write himselfe the happiest man alive;
She is Widow for a Lord; but I am fixt,
I would you had her Sir, I say no more;
She has an estate of twenty Exchequers, and
Is of so gentle soule.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: I leave you to repent
Your cruelty, my Coach—

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Please you Madam,
Doe me the grace to let me waite upon you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Now do I expect shee'l dote upon me: Ex. Gol. Bird, Simple.
Ladies, you see what fortunes I neglect,
She is a pretty handsome creature too.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: In my opinion Sir, you have not beene
So kind as shee deserves, and for my part
I have so much compassion of her sufferings,
Were all the wit of younger brothers in you,
And could you make me joynture of a Province,
I would rather marry my fathers serving man
And stand at livery my selfe than be
Wife to a man so ingratefull. Ex. Au.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: How, sweet Lady?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: My sister, Sir, is just, can you expect
An entertainement here after your scorne
Of one that nobly loves you? Ex. Chr.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I have usd a pretious policie to supplant my selfe,
She has a scruple in her conscience,
And will not wrong the Lady Bird, a pox
Vpon his Rhetoricke.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Your Lady Bird is Coach'd, and she hath tooke
Sir Gervace with her.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Their legs doe justic
In the same boote.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Why doe you laugh? What humor's this?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Sir Gervace: Ha, ha, he thinkes, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: You have a merry spleene, I know not what
He thinkes, but if he meane to retrive the Lady Bird.

sp.speaker: Cap
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Pray let me know, whence springs this suddaine mirth; I will laugh wi'yee.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Hold my sides, my buttons!

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Tis well your doublet's slash'd

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Ha, ha, next time I come, Ile discover— I sha'not
Containe my selfe i'th' streete, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: The Poet's mad indeed, farewell Democritus. Ex.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: By your favour Sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Your businesse?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I understand your name is Thornay.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: It was my fathers, and tis, upon record, that I was christened Thomas, does that concerne you Sir?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.p: I bring commends from a friend of yours.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I crave you mercy,
I am your servant. Reades the letter.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: He appeares unmov'd.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Thanke you Sir, Godbe-wi'y'.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Although I am confident
You thinke it not my office to convey
Letters so much respect I beare the Gentlewoman
That sent it, I would thinke it Sir no burden
To carry an answer to her.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: It requires none.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Shall I returne, you'l visit her in person?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I cannot promise.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I may forget it.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: With your pardon Sir, she did impose on me.
To know some resolution.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: She did?
Are you acquainted with her?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I doe beare
No great age in her knowledge.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Perhaps she has imparted the contents.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I could conjecture
By circumstance shee much desires to see you.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Cannot come; that's all—

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I must have more.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Tis a neglect becomes you not.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: You are not sent a Champion to defie me.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I have no title from her blood, and yet
Her vertue is so neere me, I must tell you,
She hath deserv'd your best esteeme.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: She has told you belike some story.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I pray see her, Ile waite upon you.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: To what purpose?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: To love and cherish her, that claimes your heart,
The office of your soule to honour her,
Does not your conscience tremble yet? what reason
Can you alledge you should not love her?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Reason? Ile shew you a reason, walk a little further.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I shall expect it. Ex.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: It must be so, and yet me thinkes I move
Without a soule, she is the first apostate
From loves religion, in that my honour
Is safe, and it is justice, my Aurelia,
This heart to thee, should now alone be sacred.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Sir, you are welcome, what not speake to me?
This is a strange neglect; I have newes for you:
Your friend—

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Tis so, he has prevaild with her,
And she will boast her change.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: He cannot be
So fixt in meditation; with your favour.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Reserve your newes, I doe not thirst to heare it.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Sure he mistakes me all this while, tis I.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: But tis not I, I see you are a woman,
I have nothing else to say. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ch
sp.p: I have not us'd him so: was there no way to expresse his purpose, without this scorne? tis not discreetly done, I could be very angry he returnes, Enter Gerard; Aurelia .With him Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I am ignorant
With what words I should meet this noble love.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I was created for this happinesse,
To these embraces which doe more than twist
Our bodies, every circle of thy armes
Enchaines my soule, that doth forget all freedome,
And willingly submit to be thy prisoner.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: It doe not grieve me that he loves my sister,

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: I am too little to containe my joy,
It flowes above the narrow banks Aurelia:
What shall I say let me bath here eternally,
And study new Arithmetick, to count
Our blessings.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Can you Sir be constant?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I, touch him there Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You doe ill
To interrupt our joyes upon this lip
That deserves all should open to commend it,
I seale the contract of my heart for ever,
I wil be nothing when I am not thine:
Suspect the starres may lose themselves in heaven,
But never I this vow, thy sister has
No part in my affection; she usurp'd
Some title, but I now have canceld all
The thoughts of her, and offer thee my selfe,
My selfe thy perfect honourer. Ex. Ger. Aur.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Wherein have I deserv'd to be thus slighted?
Is there no conflict in my blood? Can love
I beare a sister, take away all sense
Of this indignity?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Looke you Sir, I promis'd you a reason, why I could
Not love Eugenia; there's my reason, I
Doe love that Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Tis Master Thornay:
I am resolv'd, I have no other way
To punish his disdaine, than to pretend
I love this Gentleman, that he may see
I have the freedome of my soule, to mocke
His triumph, and with as much facility
Meet his neglect. Oh Master Thornay,
You are very welcome, I was wishing for you.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Hum? this entertainment is a little better
Than I expected.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: You absent your selfe too much beleeve, your visits shall not be more frequent, than your person gratefull hither.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: doe y' heare, you may returne, and tell this story
Vnto the Lady i'th inchanted Castle:
You see my fate, I cannot come; Godbe-wi'y'.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: You shall acquit your selfe more Nobly Sir,
And better satisfie her in your person.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I wo'not take the paines to see her, and
Shee were a dying.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Not to recover her.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Shall you and I Sir, walke a turne i'th Garden.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Yes Lady, Heaven vouchsafe I grow not mad
Wi'my good fortune.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: With your pardon Mistresse,
I must take priviledge to tell this man
Hee is not worthy of your favours.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: How Sir?
You doe not know my temper:

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Nor regard it. draw.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Hold as you beare respect to mee.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I am charm'd.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I should be guilty of some sinne to you
Not to reveale, this Gentleman has made
A forfeit of his honor.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Will you heare him?
Pox o'my dulnesse, what meant I to bring
Him hither? doe not credit any thing,
Wee are old enemies, and he has studied this
Device to poison your opinion of me,
A meere trick; doe not beleeve a word sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I am not easie Sir to entertaine
Malicious accusation of your fame,
Your vertue in my thoughts, is not so soone
Shaken with one report.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: That's comfort yet.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Then you provoke me to be plaine, know Lady,
Y'are i'th way to be most miserable,
Abus'd by this false man, that will betray
Your innocent beauty to so great a shame,
Repentance is not able to restore you:
He has a wife already.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: How a wife?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: A wife, if holy vowes have power to bind you:

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Doe you beleeve this? were you by
When I was married.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: No, but heaven and Angels
Are witnesses you did exchange a faith
With one that mournes a Virgin, and a Widdow:
Have you no earthquake in you? does thy soule
It selfe not feele an ague, to remember
How many kisses seald the amorous contract?
Shee meant it so, and every day her eyes
Weepe in the memory of her selfe forsaken:
And cause her griefe will not at once destroy her,
Despairing of your love, to shew how willing
Shee is to dye, doth every houre distill
Part of her soule in teares.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: This cannot bee.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Be: no, no, 'tis impossible: shall we walk sweet Lady?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Will not this excite your pitty, mercy shines bright in women.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I have heard you Sir,
And doubt not, when hee comes to answer
These imputations, hee may quit himselfe.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Would wee were both on's but to skirmish in
A saw-pit, I must cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Admit he promis'd love,
Oblig'd himselfe by oath to her you plead for,
This binds him not to undoe himselfe for ever.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Vndoe himselfe.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Yes, marriage is an act,
That doth concerne his whole life, and in something
May marre, or profit his eternity:
Perhaps the Gentlewoman, since hee gave
His faith is falne from vertue.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I have heard so.

sp.speaker: Chr
sp.l: May be turn'd prostitute.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I, who'l sweare for her?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I must not heare her nam'd with the suspition
Of such a staine.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Wee doe not Sir accuse her.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Not absolutely.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Did you but know the Creature, it would call
A blush into your face, for talking thus;
Shee has purity enough for all her sex,
And this attended with so many vertues,
As but to wish her more, it selfe were sinne.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: This Gentleman pleades for her.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Will you please to walke?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Dismisse him first.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Doe y' heare; this Lady
Is weary of your company; you have
Not us'd me like a Gentleman, indeed
Scurvily, tis no time nor place to expostulate,
But wee shall meet agen; in the meane time,
Returne, and tell the Virgin you so magnifie,
I doe not finde my selfe in any humour
To see her agen; pray her neglect no fortune,
For my sake, there be many yonger brothers
I'th Towne, will bee content to marry her:
You may resolve her what's become of me,
There is no wrastling with our fate.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Thou art not worth my answer. Exit Yon.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Ile not question Sir, this Gentlemans relation.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: You are wise.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: But in my confidence, hee hath spoke all truth:
I must desire you visit mee no more.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: You doe but jest I hope.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Ingratefull man! how are poore women coozen'd?
With what impudence couldst thou desire my favour?
Goe and make a satisfaction to the injur'd Maid,
Borne the dishonour of a man. Exit.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Am I awake? Or doe I dreame,
I am made a Coxcombe thus?
I am a Raskall, and deserve no mercy,
For abusing that poore Gentlewoman, that sent
So kindly to me; wo'd the Messenger were here agen.
Tis Master Gerard, how hath hee sped?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You are sad Aurelia; what on the sudden
Can beget this change? Are you in health?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Your blood methinkes
Is wandring from your cheeke, your eyes have lost
Their lightning too, call backe your smiles, and blesse
Him that is now your creature.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Mine? excuse me if I suspect.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I have heard you Sir.
And have considered all that you have said
To make me thinke you are now wholly mine:
I must confesse you have exprest a Lover,
Wanted no Art to flourish your warme passion:
But language is no clew to guide us to
The knowledge of your heart.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Nor is suspition a cause enough in justice to condemn.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: It is not; but where circumstances meet,
They may be thought on.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: By your beauty,
By those faire eyes, that never kil'd till now,
Make me so happy, but to know what cause
Inclines you to suspect, and I will take it
The greatest argument of love, that ever
A Virgin shew'd to man; then Ile be bold,
And with the whitenesse of my soule make such
Assurance of you, that not malice, aided
With all the devils cunning, shall be able
To interpose one scruple more against me.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You lov'd my Sister.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I did once, my Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: And you declare you can neglect her now,
Looke on her like a stranger.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis most true.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: She lov'd you well, most nobly, with as much
Fervour as ever I did or can love;
Should I thinke to be more secure than she?
Promise that firme to me, which in so fresh
A sight and memory you have violated
To her, that plac'd you in as deare a bosome?
Discretion bids me pause, I may be rash,
Either you lov'd her not at all, and so
You may play false with both, or loving her
With as much levity, I suppose you may
Forsake me too. Therfore I bid you first farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: I am blasted.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: We are both undone, I dare not see him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Was ever man so miserably lost?
Is there a balme can cure me? Oh, I bleed:
The sword wounds gently but love kils indeed. Exit.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Has truth forsooke mankind? or is it my
Fate onely to converse with those that are
So cruell and neglectfull of our sexe?
Vnhappy Maid is he not yet return'd?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: None yet appeares.

lg.l: Then I despaire to see him:
And when I thinke indeed of the imployment,
That 'tis against himselfe, I may with justice
Accuse my want of judgement, to expect
He should performe so hard an imposition:
I would I could not thinke of any man,
They rob me of my peace: I prethee try
Thy voyce, to put my heart in better tune;
There is a power in harmony, some say,
To charme the unruly motions of the braine:
Love is itselfe a melancholy madnesse:
Why should not Musicke cure the wound of love?
Melancholy hence, goe get
Some piece of earth to be thy seat,
Here the ayre and nimble fire,
Would shoot up to meet desire:
Sullen humour, leave her blood,
Mix not with the purer floud,
But let pleasures swelling there,
Make a Spring-tide all the yeere.

sp.speaker: Chry.
sp.l: How does my deare Eugenia?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: As well
As this restraint will give me leave, and yet
It does appeare a part of my enlargement
To have your company: I hope your sister
Enjoyes her health.

sp.speaker: Chry.
sp.l: And more felicity
Than I can boast mine owne, shee's halfe a Bride.
Happy ith' embraces of her wished servant;
You know our story; he ha's chosen her,
And most uncivilly neglecteth me.
Thus laden with his scorne, I come to practise
A scene of sorrow w'ye; sure thy fate
Hath spun a thread for me, we are so like
In our misfortunes: Have you heard no newe
Of your ingratefull servant, for I know
No other name, and he indeed deserves
To have no other memory, that takes
A pride in his disdaine.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Nothing as yet.
But I have met occasion to convey
A Letter to him, yet I cannot promise:
But here's the messenger.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: That Gentleman?
I know the man you love then, is't not Thornay?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: The same, I did conceale him for his shame.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Why hee's a zealous suiter for my love.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: It makes for me that he continues cruell;
I was not able to command his passion.
But will she not mistrust I have not beene
So carefull in advancing her desires,
But satisfied my selfe with any answer,
As knowing what must bring comfort to her,
Must needs be killing to my hopes? In what
A narrow path I tread; her spring must be
My frost, and when her tree carries the pride
And bloome of summer, I retaine no sap,
But wither and creepe backward into earth,
Like a forsaken plant.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Here Ile obscure. Chrysolina withdrawes.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: You are welcome, Sir.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I would I were.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Shall I beleeve you have beene faithful to
My griefes request?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Yes, and bring comfort backe.

sp.speaker: Chrys.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Pronounce those words agen.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I bring you comfort.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: He did say so: What meant she
To mocke me with another sad relation?
Was't a device in her to increase my joy
At meeting, he did talke of comfort; is it
A thing restor'd in nature? Oh, before
You blesse my eare agen with that wished sound,
Excuse my modesty, if my heart present
A kisse to thanke you.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I drinke in my poyson.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Now let your comforts flow.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I have returned you
As true a lover as yet ever Mistris
Could boast possession of, one so resolved
To honour you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Can this be possible?

sp.speaker: Yon.
