sp.l: I have examined every secret thought
Within his foule, concerning you, and dare
Thus boldly justifie, he is your owne.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Let me but live to see him, and I write
My ambition satisfied

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: He's here.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Yo.
sp.l: Here,
In me your truest servant is return'd.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Does he affect her?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I call all thats good
To witnesse with me, I discharg'd with zeale
The unkind office to my selfe, but could not
Incline him to returne to any softnesse:
In briefe, he has unworthily engag'd
That heart belonging to you, and would not be
Provoked to see you agen.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Eugenia. Chr. leads in Eug.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Is all this waking? Have I seene her faint?
And did not she that cherishes her enemy,
Haste to her reliefe, and seeme to suffer with her?
While I, as one had growne here, did not move?
I did not well, to exalt her with a hope:
To meet a blessing, and then ruine her.
If death hath whisper'd her aside, I shall
Be accused, and I will take my preferment
To be sent after her to tell her ghost
I lov'd her best; when wee are both immortall
She'l understand me better.
Is Eugenia alive agen?

sp.speaker: Chr,
sp.l: There is no danger to be fear'd; a qualme.
Pray let me aske you Sir one question,
Doe you affect this Virgin really?
I move it not for any harme.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Would she had sent hither,
But with desire to be resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: May be she has.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Then tell her I doe love her better
Than I can expresse, but when she has
Numbred all things are excellent on earth
She is to me above 'em infinitely.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: This carries no probability.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Would thou wert a man
Then I durst tell thee, I doe love her so
I durst be wicked for her, and kill thee.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: With all this, it does not appeare you love her so
And be an instrument, nay plead to put another in possession
Of your lov'd treasure; for if I mistake not
You late did urge a man, whom shee esteemed
Better, to returne and marry her:
Can any man that loves a woman truly,
Strive to supplant himselfe and give away
His comfort?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: There's the honour of my service,
When I am dead, the story shall remember
I lov'd a maid so well that I prefer'd
Whatever she desired above my selfe,
And cause she lou'd one better, was content,
To serve her wishes with my banishment:
He does not love a Virgin nobly, whose
Affection walkes not just to her desires,
To like e'm 'bove his owne.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: If this can be,
Thou art the noblest lover in the world,
With what affection shall shee be blest
That loves him, when the mistresse that esteemes
Him not, is thus rewarded?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Indeed I love him still and shall doe ever,
Nor had I now returnd to life, but that
I had not tooke my leave of him

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: More corrosive.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: If you'l oblige a Virgin,
For ever to you once more visit him,
Tell him I lye like one thats desperate sicke,
Opprest with griefe of body, and of mind,
But cannot be so fortunate to quit
The world till he vouchsafe to visit me.
Bid him not feare I will detaine him long
With idle talke, sixe words and I am dead.
Although he love me not, he may doe this:
If you will adde this to your other worke,
I will impose no more, indeed I will not:
So farewell noble Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: If you will please to joyne with me, I doubt not
To effect her wishes.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: You doe not know what power I have with him.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: You have too much

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Ile undertake—

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: You sha'not rob me of the reward.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: What reward?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Perhaps another kisse; pray tell her, I
Went cheerefully to finish her command. Exit.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I doe admire and love this noble temper,
What flames are these? Suppresse 'em, they grow high,
If he affect her so, what hope have I? Ex.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Mad? why you still enjoy discourse.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: What then? may not a man be mad, and yet talke wisely?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: But few in my experience.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Doe not abuse thy knowledge, at the worst
Thou canst but say, our senses are deprav'd,
Throwne off o'th' hinge; the tongue is none I hope,
Though some would have the titillation
Ioynd to make up a sixth in the grave Synode:
Beleeve then I am mad; Ile prov't by reason.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: By reason? that's a new way to prove it;
But Ile heare no reason.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Then thou art mad thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Nay, I thinke I am madder o'th two,
And have as much reason, if there bee reason
Able to make one mad; but let's be wise:
Or if it must be that y'ave lost your wits,
Let's see and wee can recover e'm by drinking;
For hee that is not sober after drunkennesse,
Is no man of this world.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now thou talkest wildly.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.p: I talke wildly, that would justifie my selfe to bee in my wits, and you that talk reason and sense wo'not beleeve y'ave any.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: If it bee so, that may conclude I ha' lost 'em,
And doe not understand my selfe.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: So, so, I should beleeve another in that argument,
But not you, for in knowing that, you prove
You are no mad-man.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Prethee tell mee, thou art a peece of a Philosopher,
And knowest the naturall causes.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Hold in that; I must confesse, you are little
Beside your selfe: I a Philosopher?
I studied Titelman sometimes i'th College,
As others did, and wanting Epictetus
Lanthorne, slept alwaies with a watching Candle
In my study window, and might very well
Dreame over learning o'my Deske, or so;
What Aristotle might infuse into
My sleepes I know not, but waking I nere troubled
My selfe to understand him; true I lov'd
His Booke De Coelo, for the heavenly Title,
And made my Father buy it, for my study
Of Divinity, told him I would be a Bishop;
That brought me threescore pound a yeere for sacke:
I prethee doe not talke of learning.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Why then acknowledge, I am mad, and I have done.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Well for this once I will allow it, th'art mad.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: But wherefore doe y'allow it, what's the cause?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Nay, nay, I know not that.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Ile tell thee then.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Tis come about agen.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And let thy judgement censure mee
If I produce not able reasons—

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: To prove madnesse, he makes me mad to heare him;
Now I consider better on't, I confesse
You have some cause to be a little mad,
The losse of such a Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: But of one?
Did they not both affect mee, and I them
With such equality of honour.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Grant it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And I to lose 'em both? faith speake but honestly;
Is't not a wonder that I doe not rave
And kill my selfe? how many have runne mad
For one that never lov'd 'em? and shall I
Bee so unmannerly not to lose my wits
For two and two such creatures? twere a Solecisme
In love: I prethee doe not flatter mee
With an opinion that I have my reason;
It cannot bee, it is against all sense,
I should haue any; such an expectation
Lost, is enough to make the genius
Of all the world runne mad, and I will straight.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: To Bedlem, whether should I goe?
I must not live in this community of fooles and wisemen.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: There be Knaves among us.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Here all are happy, there I sha'not meet
With lovers that are fortunate, but with men
Of my complexion, that looke twenty wayes
At once, that sigh and curse, and sing mad Carols:
If I can get to bee their Prince, Ile make
A law it shall bee death to smile or kisse
A woman.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Now I feare him.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Nay, wee'le have
An excellent well governd Common wealth,
A delicate Eutopia, there shall be
Lectures and publike readings shall put downe
Gressams foundation for the liberall Arts,
And make the Citizens bring their Shop-bookes hither
To take fine notes, how to bee paid their debts,
And yet trust none but younger brothers: then
Wee will have penall Statutes against eating,
Live all by the ayre of commendations.
No idle man shall live within our State:
Doe y' marke? they are the mouthes of the Republike:
And therefore hee that has no other worke
To prevent slothfulnesse, may imploy his time
In picking strawes, there will be a great plenty.
Here will wee live together, and bee mad
Perpetually, wee wo'not bee recovered;
For if at any time wee incline to bee
Sober, and comming to our wits againe,
The lash will whip us into new distempers
And mad fugaries.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Doe y' know all this while
What you have said, you correct me for speaking
Extravagantly, and yet talke wilde your selfe.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I prethee pardon and instruct me better; I am not well.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Will you walke to your Chamber, Ile beare you company.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: No, I am well againe.
Vpon condition you will tell Aurelia
Shee did not use me kindly.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: She did not use me kindly, nothing else, Farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I know not what to thinke on him,
The unhappinesse was so sudden, and unlook'd for,
It might disturbe his fancy, but I hope
The worst is past, a little rest will settle him.
But which way shall I recompence the injury:
I ha' done him? and I had not been ungratefull
To Eugenia, wee might have both beene happy.
Ha? 'tis hee: Save you most Noble Sir;
Ift please you now, Ile goe along with you
Toth' Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: What Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Eugenia, that wrote the Letter to me, I meane her.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I ha' considered better, & doe meane
To make her satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: 'Tis too late:
You might have done this earlier, your love
Will appeare now unseasonable, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Pray give me a reason.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: D'ye not blush to aske it?
I told her what you said, and now we are
Resolv'd; you cannot blame her, she was covetous
To embrace you; but your answer being return'd
So peremptorily in her neglect, we both agreed.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: You both? Why what was that to you?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: That doubt will cleere it selfe when we are married.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Why, did you love her?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: And deserve her best
Of all the world: and yet shee'd give me no
Assurance till she knew your resolution,
Which I was able to informe her, and
'Tis now a bargaine; upon munday next.—

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Your wedding day.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: In very good time. You weare a sword.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Ile only try how you can fence, I must not lose her so.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: You lose her? you despis'd her, wo'd not see her,
Not to recover her from death. D'yee not
Remember such a saying, In the Towne
Were many yonger brothers, that might be
Content to marry her; let her use her fortune,
For your owne part, you were engag'd, there was
No wrestling with your fate: Was it not so?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: 'Tis all one for that, my mind is altred,
I'm of another humour now, and will
Maintaine, I love her better than you dare.

sp.speaker: Yo.
sp.l: Then I must tell you.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Tell me no tellings:
Either resigne her to me againe, or—

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Resolve me, pray, can you affect her heartily?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Else let me perish on your sword.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I heard
You court another Mistris, that did answer it with entertainment.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: She was a very Gipsie.
You were no sooner parted, but she us'd me
Basely; 'tis true, I did sufficiently
Deserve it, for my breach of vow to her
I now alone doe honour, and for whom,
(Chang'd into honesty) I will rather dye
Than live without her.

sp.speaker: Yo.
sp.l: Heaven do's heare all this.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I make no doubt, and while my heart to her
Is reconcil'd, cannot despaire of mercie.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: You shall have her.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Shall I? then Ile love thee too.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: And know, she ha's no thought but to be yours,
There ha's no obligation past betwixt us two:
I came for this: yet I must tell you, Sir,
I love her too, and shall doe ever.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: How? not when
She is my wife, I hope.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Yes then.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: If you have cut her up, and left her cold meat,
I shall lose my stomacke.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: With a holy flame,
Her vertue keeps a Vestall fire within me,
But she affects not me, yet I might challenge her:
Nor can you ever, but in right of me,
Glory your selfe possest; I have bought her.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I hope she ha's not sold her maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Yo.
sp.l: Her vncle
(Whose aime is onely profit) hath concluded
With me a price for her, and therefore gives
Accesse to none, till I ha' prov'd my fortune;
But I finde her devoted to you onely,
And have conform'd my wishes unto hers;
She loves you best, and I preferre you too,
Returne, and be her husband, Ile direct you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You understand my purpose, you shall make
The Dance, let me alone to write the songs.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: A Maske will be delightfull to the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Oh Sir, what Playes are taking without these
Pretty devices? Many Gentlemen
Are not, as in the dayes of understanding.
Now satisfied without a Iigge, which since
They cannot, with their honour, call for, after
The play, they looke to be serv'd up ith' middle:
Your dance is the best language of some Comedies,
And footing runnes away with all; a Scene
Exprest with life of Art, and squar'd to nature,
Is dull and flegmatick Poetry.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Enough;
I am bound to honour thee, command my life,
Thou excellent young man.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I wish you happinesse and never after her will love a woman.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You know my lodging.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Ile attend you Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I wonder what's become of my hermophrodyte?
Yongrave, how is't man? what art melancholy?
What hath hung plummets on thy nimble soule,
What sleepie rod hath charmd thy mounting spirit?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Prethee enjoy thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: By Parnassus
You must not be so head hung, why dost peep—
Vnder thy cloake as thou didst feare a Serjeant?
Who are these? my wish! fortune hath sent thee a cure,
The rarest mirth! you sha'not lose it, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: You have strangely wonne me to obey you Sir,
I refuse nothing you command.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Shalt go,
And heare how I will talke, and baffle 'em:
But what if wee meet Caperwit?

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: No matter.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: No: w'y then let him goe hang himselfe in his owne verses, if the lines be strong enough, come my Nightingale, my Bird of Paradise. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: If ever thou didst love me, lets follow 'em;
Feede not this sullen humour, Ile promise excellent sport.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: You shall prevaile. Ex.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: It was not kindly done, beleeve me sister,
He did performe but our request.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Tis granted;
But his neglect of you afflicted me.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: He could not make you happy, and remaine
Servant to me.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Nor make me blest, while you
Seem'd discontented.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Doe not thinke I was,
I did but carry trouble in my face,
When he declared himselfe withdrew my smiles,
For your sake, to make you appeare most lovely,
And worthy of his choice; and could you be
So cruell to reject him, when he came
To be confirm'd your owne without a rivall?
It seemes he did not know who lov'd him best.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Best?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Yes, and I in this, will mak't appeare,
That now you have exild him from your love,
Ile sue for his affection.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: He is mine.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: But you Aurelia are not his; I will
Appeale to his modest reason, that shall guide
His eye to looke on both agen, I doe not
See what in me should not invite him hither,
With as much ardor, rather more, since he
Hath prov'd already your too much unkindnesse;
What if this noble Gentleman should lose
His wits upon 't, will all your beautie call
His straggling senses to their seate agen?
Ile seeke him out betimes and comfort him.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Tis more than will become you sister.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: And it must bring your modesty in question,
To follow one that cares not for you

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Thus
I may awake his noble flame, nor is it
Any dishonor when the world shall know
How you have us'd him, if I make returne,
To what I lov'd so deerely.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Not while I may challeng interest; here are company
sp.stage: Enter Simple, Bird, Yongrave, Caperwit aloofe.
sp.l: Let us withdraw, I have something more to tell you.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Deferre it rather now; here comes my hope.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: How's this? nay then Ile stay a little longer.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: By your leave Gentlewomen, I should mock you
To call you Ladies; perhaps you may wonder at me.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I see no cause.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Have you no eyes?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Such as you see?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Oh eyes no eies but Mountaines fraught with teares!

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Hee's turnd Ieronymo.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: Goe by, Ieronymo, goe by, goe by. He passeth by them with disdaine.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Doe y' know where you are?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Yes, and to whom I speake I hope.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Noble Sir, I hope you doe not scorne us.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Scorne you, no; but I doe not care a rush for you, you might have had me when I was offered, tis none of my fault, and you doe fall to eating of chalke, and dye oth' black jaundise, I cannot helpe it now for I proclaime, here is the what doe y' call it, of my heart.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Has he wonne this Lady? I suspect her:
I hope you have not quite forsaken me;
Virgins for custome sake, sometimes deny,
Beleeve me Sir, when you did plead for love
My heart did not so much as think on't.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Nay tis no matter, I ha' tooke my course, yet I
Have a sute to you that you would not breake your heart,
Nor you, to see us kisse. Nectar! immortall nectar! He kisses Bird.
Oh let this Diamond purchase such another,
Tis pitty that my lips should ever open,
To let the breath she gave me, out agen.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Doe y' pay so much for every kisse? a Diamond?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I never offer lesse to touch her lip; marry her hand, or her a— or foote or so, I may salute for a ruby, or an emrode or a satire; or so, but I have stones— now doe thou speake a little for their further mortification.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: I did not thinke to have returnd so soone
A trouble to you but the importunity
Of this most worthy Gentleman prevail'd,
I thinke there was some Magick in his tongue.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay you may sweare that, the wisest in the country, thought my mother a Witch.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: He did no sooner open his desires,
But he did wound my heart, you see his bounty,
What jewels hee has given mee.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: All thine owne; somebody else might ha' been wise and had'em.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Somebody else might have been wise, and kept 'em.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: I must confesse, I lov'd another lately, but his affection's frozen up—

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Blesse you bevy of Ladies.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Sir, you are come most seasonably, before
These Gentlewomen, I release your promise,
My thoughts are fixt upon this Noble Knight,
Affect now where you please; here is my husband.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You are not married?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: No, but I came to bid you all to my wedding, I have
Bespoke Gloves, and Points, and knacks, and knaveries.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I will dye Hymens Saffron robe in blood,
Put out the Torches with the teares of Virgins,
And make the Temple quake.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Will you so Sir?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Excellent Rascall!

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: There is no way but to acknowledge it,
It is no shame in love, there's no disgrace,
For else by Law he may recover mee.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Doe y' heare Sir, you may take her if you please, but if she be troubled with a timpany, there is a man within a mile of an Oke, I name no-body, that has had,— some earnest of her body.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I hope you doe but jest.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Ile make all sure; what a loving Lady is this?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Then I require you give me back this Diamond,
The token once I gave of my devotion.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Why that's mine, I gave it her but now before all this company.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.p: Be wise and let him have it, 'tis like his within my Cabinet, let's be quit on him, this will secure our marriage.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Let him have it there bee more in Cheapeside, but let's not tarry any longer Bird, hee'le challenge all the rest of thy fethers.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.p: I will obey you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Farewell beauties and kind Gentleman, if you come to my wedding, I name no time, nor place, wee'l be very merry, excellent cheere Ile promise you, your belly full of Fidlers.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ha, Ha. Exit Sim. and Bir.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What did you meane? that Ring was his.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: The Boy shall ha't agen: ha, ha, you do not know the mysterie, this Lady is a boy, a very crackrope boy.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I made him first disguise himselfe.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Yes faith, to come to you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Then I must tell you Sir, you have not us'd us civilly, to make our conversation ridiculous, To talke and complement with a Boy.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sweet Lady, by Hyppocrene—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Doe y' not thinke your wit found out a precious device to make me love you by a president; is this your great Lady?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Doe but heare mee speake.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Not now, I know you have art enough to excuse it,
Yet I am not mercilesse, let mee entreate
Your absence, without ceremony, when
You come agen, your talke will bee more musicall.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Doe's shee not prophesie the conceit, I goe
The Maske will doo't, more musicall? tis so. Exit.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Then hee's gone to her

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Hee did promise mee.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Let other Virgins when they heare this story
Wonder, but give mee leave to love you for it,
Indeed I doe; looke not so strange, your vertue
Compels mee to reaveale it, tis no shame
To owne a passion, kindled by such goodnesse.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: If I doe understand you, give mee pardon,
To thinke you are not perfectly advis'd;
I am a prisoner still to my Eugenia.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Shee is satisfied, and you are disingaged.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: But shee has not yet resignd the heart I gave,
Nor can I thinke of any other Mistresse;
Choose in a plenty of more happy men,
I gave too much away to love agen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I will retire to blush and weepe.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Not so.
Alas poore sister, now I feare you not,
I see your purpose was to make mee kinde:
I wo'd hee were my brother, but let's in
And joyne our heads, some counsell would doe well,
Tis pitty wee two should leade Apes in hell. Exit.

div.head: Actus Quintus.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: MAy I beleeve my selfe so fortunate?
Art thou return'd, or doe I dreame thus happily?
Are these my Thornays armes? are those his lips?
Can hee repent his cruelty and love?
How soone are all my teares dryed up? I doe
Forgive my griefes, and thinke they have been modest,
And gentle sufferings, who can merit such
A joy, that has not felt a world of sorrow?
Let us imbrace agen, and if thou canst
Confirme mee yet more, that I am awake,
And taste my true delight.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: By this, and this: Kisses.
Through which, if it were possible, I durst
Convey my soule, I am for ever thine,
Created new to bee made worthy of thee,
I have beene dead too long to thee, and vertue,
Committed sinne enough, in my neglect
Of thee, to plant a fierce, and deepe antipathy
In every womans heart against mankind;
But you are mercifull, and imitate
The eternall nature.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Ha? how is this? a kissing?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: We are betraid.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: So now tis done; I would not
Be engag'd to kisse you againe, for all the estate.
Your father left you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I hope my breath has not offended you.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I cannot tell, I ha' not kist a woman this twelve-moneth, and had not done this, but that he had my oath to performe it; well you have the lip labour he sent you, Master Yongrave is well, will see you agen shortly— Godbe-wi'y'.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Pray stay a little.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: You'l send him such another token; imploy your waiting woman, I am no common kisse-carrier.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.p: Oh ho, is't not otherwise, hee is a messenger from Master Yongrave, y'are welcome Sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: And I be not, I am going Sir, to the place from whence I came Sir?

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.p: How does Master Yongrave?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: As foolish as ever, he is still in love—

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.p: I pray commend me to him.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: You may now commend your selfe, he is here.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Oh let me flie into his armes and boast
Never had woman such a noble servant,
Blest was that minute Vncle, in which you
First knew this Gentleman; more blessed I,
That doe enjoy by him, that which my heart
Next heaven affecteth most; 'twill be an age
Till holy Church confirmes our vowes, I cannot
Mannage the comforts you have given mee,
I did not thinke I should so soone have met
A husband, Vncle.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: I am glad to heare it.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Command thy truest servant, nothing wants
But how to get her forth, 'twere soone dispatch'd.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Sir, we resolve not to lose any time,
We'l marry instantly.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: The licence will be at Church, as soone as we,
Then I shall quickly make you perfect owner,
Of all those lands, that lye so neere your Lordship;
You have security, I shall performe
When we are man and wise.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Right, Master Yongrave?
You are an honest Gentleman, my Neece
May glorie in such a choice, I have some businesse,
Excuse three minutes, Ile dispatch, and goe
Along with you my selfe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: How's that? he go? we must prevent that mischiefe.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Noble Sir, what service can reward this goodnesse in you?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: If you acknowledge any benefit
From me, in that I am enough rewarded,
I wish you, what I cannot hope for, joy,
But yet we have not finish'd.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What doe y' thinke? if—
Tis gone againe, wee must have some tricke,
To get off without him.

div.stage: Enter Servant with a letter to Eugenia.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: From Mistresse Chrysolina?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What and we should set some on's house a-fire,
Doe y' thinke he would stay to quench it? how has he
Liv'd all this while, and has no more diseases?
No honest Gout to keepe him warme at home,
In furres, no charitable Ague, fall
Into his legges to stay him, no Sciatica?
He is no Gentleman he scapes so well.

p.quote: I love him above my life, but you have only his heart, he sayes; for which I languish, if you have power to dispose it, I will cherish some hope, he will love me, at least for your sake.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: If he should with us, is't not possible
sp.p: He may have a fall, and breake a leg, and t'were but his neck, why may not some prentice throw a stone, and put an eye out, that he may goe to th' Surgeons, or some horse, or cart-wheele squeeze his toe, and stay his journey?

p.quote: His noble carriage to you, made me first affect him, then since you are happy in another, let me owe to your vertue for his affection, without whom I am the most miserable— Chrysolina.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Let me entreate you Sir, peruse that paper.
Sir you know Chrysolina?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I doe know her.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Poore Gentlewoman is in love with Yongrave:
Wee have arriv'd at our desires already,
And want but the Church sealing, she is lost,
Vnlesse he meet her wishes, 'twill become
Our piety to advance, in what wee may
The common cause of love, then briefely thus—

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Can any Virgin affect me so much?
She did prepare this argument before.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: As you are charitable, goe presently.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And leave you thus?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: We'l get off, well enough: Eug. and Thor. whisper.
Pray her to meete us.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I doe pitty her,
And I have learn'd it from my sufferings;
But I must keepe my word, Eugenia
Hath still my heart, and onely can dispose it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Then I resigne to her, in this alone,
I will deserve these noble offices.
You know the place.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I'm perfect.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Love her, and let us all be happy.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Sir, I must desire
You would excuse me, I would goe with you,
But that I have considered, 'twill be better
That I should not appeare, since you intend
To have it private, there will be lesse notice
If I be absent, and it may be thought
You by some tricke stole her away: D'yee marke?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Well thought on.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Then, sir, that opinion
Will save our credit, and excuse the want
Of ceremony, and the fruitlesse charge,
Which is expected at her marriage:
Is it not best?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: You shew your providence.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Though I could wish your presence.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Y'are not wise,
Eugenia, goe to the Church, and let me
Salute you quickly happy bride and bridegroome:
Away, I say.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: He ha's prevented us. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: The Land's my own, you wrong your joyes to tarry,
I would I had more Neeces thus to marry. Exit.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Nay, never blush, but haste and meet the Gentleman.
You have no reason to distrust me, Lady,
After this circumstance.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Can I be so happy?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Have a strong faith, and finde it so,
Though once I was guilty of some wrong to thee.

sp.speaker: Chry.
sp.l: Never to me: or if you had this newes
Is recompence enough.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Ile tell thee now:
I was the cause that Gerard did neglect thee,
In hope to gaine thee for my selfe; I told him
Thou had'st halfe consented to be mine.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: This truth?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Bade him direct his Courtship to Aurelia,
And so be sure of one: poore Gentleman
Beleev'd, and after lost thy sister too:
But if no cure be seasonably apply'd,
Gerard, I feare, will sinke beneath his losse.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Was this the cause?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I must accuse my selfe.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Ile tell Aurelia this.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Doe so.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: She meant to visit him, but this wil give her wings.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I will intreat her pardon, but make haste,
I wo'd not willingly be seene.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I feele
Another soule, what raptures are distill'd
Vpon my heart? Enter Caperwit.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: She cannot choose but take it.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: You know how to direct her, but be swift
In your returne.— Mr. Caperwit?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Your servant.
Sir, if my sight be not unfaithfull, I have seene you.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I owe much to your eyes,
It was my happinesse to see you here.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I doe remember.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I observ'd your courtship
To faire Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Pray sir, can you dance?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Dance?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I presume you are a friend to her,
Whose name made sweet your breath so late.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: It did not stinke before.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Excuse my Poetry.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Cry you mercy.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I know y'ave heard wherein consists my excellence.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: You are a Prince in Poetry, & please your Excellence.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: The phrase in Latine's modest, use no reverence,
To tell you true, you are a friend, I am upon a Maske—

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: That made you aske if I could dance.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: 'Tis right, and you should doe me honour
To lend your person to it, but I wo'd
Have it this night, before my Mistris, whose
Mention perfum'd your lips so late.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Sweet language!
Wy' your favour, Mr. Caperwit, who are the
Principall Maskers?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Faith I have none yet,
Beside my selfe, but a foolish Knight, one Sir Gervace,
And's Lady, I want persons.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Let me furnish you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: And tye my everlasting friendship to you.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: They shall be of quality, most of your acquaintance:
What if Aurelia be one? she loves you,
I ha' discovered that; I know shee'l do't,
Her Sister for another, and my selfe,
Frank Gerard and Iack Yongrave, with his Mistris.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: The number I desire.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I know your lodging, say no more, Ile bring 'em,
This afternoone to practise, we may soone
Perfect a dance.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Shall I trust to you?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Here's my hand.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I kisse it.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I may give you a hint perhaps for the device too.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I have no other gratitude but this,
Live but a weeke, Ile send you an Ode; or dye,
Ile write your Epitaph. Exit.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I have no purpose to put your Muse
To such expence. Farewell Phantasma.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Have I not beene tedious?
I told my sister all, and she is gone
To Mr. Gerard, if their meeting prosper,
I have directed where to find us.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Excellent, come, let's away,
A thousand joyes expect us. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Gerard in his gowne and cap.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I once beleev'd women were full of pitty,
Of soft and gentle constitutions:
But I have found 'em cruell: for Aurelia,
One of the best of all her sex, doth owne
A hard and tyrannous nature. Enter servant.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir, tis done.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I prethee let it be vndone, as I am.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Song,

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I gave to be taught Musicke? Ile hear't anon:
I prethee goe—

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: To Prison.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Yes, and aske when are the Sessions.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: They are every moneth.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I would 'twere execution day to morrow.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why, with your pardon, doe you wish it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I would intreat the Surgeons to beg
Some Woman for Anatomy, nothing else:
I have heard their Lectures very much commended,
And I'd be present when they read upon
Her heart: for sure there is much difference
Betweene a Woman and a Man, in that
Same thing we call a heart, they doe not love
As we doe; we are fooles, indeed we are,
To dote so much upon 'em, and betray
The glory of our creation, to serve
A female pride; we were borne free, and had
From the great Maker Royall priviledge,
Most brave immunities: but since have made
Tame forfeit of our Charter. Let me see't,
It is the same, first read it, reach the chaire:
Tis yet no Song, infuse a soule into it.

div.head: Song.
div.l: If Love his Arrowes shoot so fast,
Soone his feathered stocke will waste:
But I mistake in thinking so,
Love's Arrowes in his Quiver grow:
How can he want Artillery?
That appeares too true in mee:
Two shafts feed upon my brest,
Oh, make it Quiver for the rest,
Kill me with love, thou angry sonne
Of Cytherea, or let one,
One sharpe golden Arrow flye,
To wound her heart for whom I dye.
Cupid, if thou bee'st a Childe,
Be no god, or be more milde.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I have not, since I serv'd him, knowne him so
Opprest with melancholy; hee's asleepe,
I dare not wake him.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Ile expect a while.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: This quiet will much benefit him, hee
Began to talke idly.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Heaven preserve the temper of his braine.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He wakes.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Ha, tis not shee, doe I dreame still;
Come hither, dost thou see nothing?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yes, a Gentlewoman that came to visit you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Doe not abuse thy master, 'tis not possible Aurelia
Will doe me so much honour; in my sleepe
Me thought I parled with her, and my fancy
Hath not yet lost her shape; Oh my Aurelia!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I come to aske thy pardon.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Doe not mocke me.
Thou wo't bee cruell when I wake agen;
And then I shall repent I dream't so sweetly.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Y'are now awake, and I am your Aurelia,
That if you can forgive her past neglect,
Will give you proofe of her repentance,
But these teares—

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Let not the ground be hallowed with
Such water, I have a heart to drinke this Balsome:
Enough Aurelia, doe not make thy eyes
Poore, to enrich thy bosome, where the drops
Shew like a Carkanet of Pearle upon it,
Thou hast enough restor'd mee.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Oh my Gerard!
Thou art too mercifull, and dost forgive
Too soone the injury I did thy love;
But I am come to make thee satisfaction;
And this is but a shadow of those joyes,
Wee must divide, if you vouchsafe to follow,
As I direct.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Tis sinne not to obey.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You must walk then.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: It is to heaven thou goest.
Convey mee swiftly thither.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Nay, tis hast is now required.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: What blisse can bee deny'd,
A man that followes such an Angell-guide? Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Thum.
sp.p:
Where in the name of simplicity, should my Master be all this while? I have been at sixe Ordinaries, twelve Tavernes,
and I thinke foure and twenty Bawdy-houses, places that Gentlemen use to frequent, and yet cannot find him: well, I am resolv'd to aske every man I meet; and if I cannot heare of him the sooner, Ile have him cryed.
Pray did you see my Master?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.p: Thy Master? I know him not.

sp.speaker: Thump.
sp.p: Nay Sir, did you see him? for if you see him, you cannot choose but know him; for hee had a hundred markes brought him warme out of the Country this morning.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.p: Much good doe it him next his heart, I see him not. Ex.

sp.speaker: Thump.
sp.p: No, no; there is no hope, 'tis but an unmannerly tricke of any Master, to leave his man o'this fashion; tis well there is no presse abroad, no disguis'd Constables twelve pence, and the Kings name would put mee into a pittifull Feaver, and I should curse Sir Gervace in another Country, as often as I heard the report of a Musket, for bringing me up no better, that might ha' hv'd quietly at home, and gone a feasting with the train'd Band without any danger.
Here is another youth, and his commodity, I'le enquire of him, Pray did you see my Master?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.p: Thy Master, what's he.

sp.speaker: Thum.
sp.p: A Knight Sir, Ile assure you, of the last edition that Was my foolish Master, for want of a better.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.p: His name?

sp.speaker: Thum.
sp.p: Sir Gervace Simple.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.p: Something of a blacke complexion, with a weezell face.

sp.speaker: Thum.
sp.p: The same Sir.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.p: In a doublet of Orange-tawny Satten, richly laced? and blew trunke hose very sutable?

sp.speaker: Thum.
sp.p: Very right Sir.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.p: A long Italian Cloake came down to his elbowes, a Spanish Ruffe, and long French stockings.

sp.speaker: Thump.
sp.p: Iust the same, how happy was I to meet with this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.p: Faith honest friend, I saw none such.

sp.speaker: Thum.
sp.p: Pox o' these questions.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.p: But if thou'lt goe with me, I may chance helpe to a sight of this Pageant.

sp.speaker: Thum.
sp.p: Heaven blesse your worship, and the sweet fac'd modicum in your company. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: To prison with your servants Husband; hang
Them all, unlesse they finde our daughters.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: And I have sent to Sir Iohn Woodhamores,
They may be with his Neece.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: They never us'd
Thus to absent themselves; Oh me unhappy!

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Wee have been too indulgent.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: I would have had them more restrain'd, yong wenches
That have so many sutors, grow soone wanton,
And throw off their obedience; had you been
Forward as I, they had been married;
And then wee had not suffered this perplexity.
I did commend an honorable man,
But your deliberation hath mar'd all,
And they were here agen—

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Have patience wife,
They are not lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: No, no, lost?
They'l come agen, double I warrant you,
And perhaps treble, with some unthrift husbands,
Of their owne choosing.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: It does trouble me.
They were not us'd to walke abroad without
A servant, to waite on 'em.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: You must thinke
They have servants of their owne, for such a businesse,
Young maids have plentie of such waiting men,
And this has beene a long conspiracy, Ile lay my life.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: What hast found 'em yet?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I can heare no newes,
And Sir Iohn Woodhamore is much troubled Sir,
His Neece is gone too.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Hey day!

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sh'as been absent
Ever since morning.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Pretious, pretious theeves!
Eugenias gone, lets have 'em cried together.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: They that have found em, will too soone I feare,
Alter the property.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: We shall keepe no virgins ith towne shortly.
Welcome Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Is not my Neece Eugenia here?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Not here.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: Wee have lost our daughters, and that's two for one.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Ours have been absent ever since the morning.
Nor can we study what's become on 'em

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Is't possible? is there no plot in this?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Our servants have enquired in every place.
Of our acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: I will tell you Sir,
You doe remember Master Yongrave.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: A servant of your Neeces;

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: The same Sir
With my consent, he tooke her forth this morning.
To marry her, I doe beleeve he has don't,
But it doth wracke my braine, why they should stay thus,
They might have married, forty times by this.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: You did perhaps desire it private.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: And he too.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: I will engage my life they are all together.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Doe you thinke so?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: I am confident, lets in to supper, and expect the best.
sp.stage: Enter Servant, and whispers Mistresse Goldsworth.
sp.l: What newes with him?

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: Tis something that he sayes.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I cannot find em.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: But I have met a Gentleman, that can
Tel you some newes.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: That does concerne my daughters?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: So he reports, he is a cunning man, I think a conjurer,
He talkes of art, and spirits.
This is he Sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Gentles in your troubled brow,
I read what you desire to know,
Let no feare invade your heart;
I will tell by powerfull art,
Your Childrens fate, and where they are:
Know then, they are wandred farre,
Led by Cupid God of loves,
They have now arriv'd those groves,
Where no happie soule can sleepe,
Venus doth there revels keepe.
Consecrating day and night,
To song, to kisses, and delight:
They in Elysium breath, chuse whether,
They shall move thence, or you goe thither.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: This is some Poeticall businesse.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Sweet husband let us goe to 'em, I have heard Poets talke much of Elysium, I would faine see whither they be honest of their words or no.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: No it will befit them to come to us.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: It shall be so: harmonious straines,
That doe blesse those happy plaines;
Vsher them forth, and shame the spheares,
Charme with heavenlier notes our eares,
Recorders .That when we see the lovers come,
We may beleeve Elysium
It selfe come hither, all those bowers,
And the shades of pleasure ours.

div.stage: Enter mask'd Yongrave, Chrysolina, Gerard, Aurelia, Thornay Eugenia, Simple Bird, betweene every couple a torch carried, they march ouer the Stage, and Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Who are all these?

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: I ghesse some of them, oh that I were in Elysium

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: What are they vanished? Another turne of your art Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Chime other musicke.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.p: Now they will discover. Master Yongrave? I rejoyce Yon. discovers .To see you here, this is the Gentleman I prais'd so much, hee has Married now my Neece.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: But I must aske your blessing, we are married,

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Chris. unveiles .Ha, another Sweetheart; I am abus'd, hee is a very Knave; where is my Neece?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Is hee worse for marrying of my child? nay, then my Blessing on you both, my sonne and daughter.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Aur. unveiles .Where's Aurelia?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Here Mother, I have met a Husband too, let us divide your Prayers— soft Master Caperwit Ger. discovers .wee are married Sir already.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: How married? did not you promise mee?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Master Gerard? nay and it be no worse I care not rise to my heart.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: My duty shall deserve it, tis ene so, good Master Caperwit you must dance without her.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Have I made verses and studied speeches for this?

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Since there's no remedy, I blesse you both, but I did Eug. unveiles .wish—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Sir: if you will acknowledge your Neece.
You must accept a Nephew too: we are as fast as they.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Death! I am coozend, cheated, there is law.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: And there is conscience.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Ile not give you a penny.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I will not publish Sir your avarice,
Wish em good joy.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Well, tis done.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Yes faith Vncle, wee are coupled, man and wife.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Ile enquire how this came about hereafter;
Looke you love her Sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: As I will doe my soule.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Gentlemen, all is not yet discovered; there are a paire behind, worth taking notice of; doe y know Sir Gervace Simple, I am the man.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: Simple as he stands there.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And this is my Lady— what does thy haire come off already.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Your worship is a most egregious coxcombe.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: A boy? Gentlemen, have I married a boy, or is shee metamorphis'd?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.p: Ha, ha, Master Caperwits Page.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Give you joy Sir.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: The Bird is flowne indeed law.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Bird? they make a coxcombe of me.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I am glad somebody else is coozend beside my selfe;
Nay, nay take her, there is a man within a mile of an Oake,
I name no body, has had earnest of her body.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Bawdy quoth a Thumpe, I will sell thee my Knighthood for halfe the mony it cost me, and turne Yeoman in the Country agen; why there is neither wit nor honesty in this.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: Be ruld by me, lets to some Taverne, and
Drinke away melancholy.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I, and then we may steale away disguisd, a match!

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Nay, nay, lets all together, and make a merry night on t, Sim. Why how now Thumpe, are you sneaking away?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Lets all together.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.p: But first we must the licence of these Gentlemen.

div.head: Epilogus.
div.l: OVr Poet knowes you will be just, but we
Appeale to mercy, he desires that yee
Would not distaste his Muse, because of late
Transplanted, which would grow here, if no fate
Have an unlucky bode opinion
Comes hither but on crutches yet, the Sun
Hath lent no beame to warme us, if this Play
Proceed more fortunate, wee shall blesse the day,
And love that brought you hither; tis in you
To make a little sprigge of Laurel grow,
And spread into a grove, where you may sit,
And hear soft stories, when by blasting it,
You gaine no honour, though our ruines lye
To tell the spoiles of your offended eye:
If not for what we are, for alas here
No Roscious moves to charme your eyes, or eare,
Yet as you hope hereafter to see Playes,
Encourage us and give our Poet bayes. Exeunt.
